statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
The Los Angeles Clippers almost made Dennis
Johnson's NBA coaching debut a successful one.

related.description: The Los Angeles Clippers fired Alvin Gentry on Monday and named Dennis Johnson interim coach for the remainder of the season.
related.linkText: Disappointing season leads to Gentry's firing by Clippers
related.title: Johnson named interim coach for rest of season
related.headline: Johnson named interim coach for rest of season

related.description: The Clippers have talent, but don't expect Donald Sterling to hire a big-name coach to work with it.
related.title: Sterling won't part with big money for big-time coach
related.headline: Sterling won't part with big money for big-time coach

article.headline: Mashburn scores 35 as Hornets hang on in L.A.

images.name: Johnson_Dennis 030303 Inline
images.caption: Dennis Johnson, who lost out on the Clippers job in 2000, could be at the helm in '03-04.

article.linkText: Clippers come close, but can't win Johnson's debut
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The Los Angeles Clippers almost made Dennis Johnson's NBA coaching debut a successful one.
Mashburn

Jamal Mashburn scored 35 points and had 10 assists for New Orleans and Andre Miller missed a 25-footer at the buzzer as the Hornets barely held off the Clippers 111-108 Monday night for their seventh consecutive victory. Johnson, a Clippers assistant coach for the past four seasons and a member of three NBA championship teams during his 14 seasons as a player, was promoted hours before the game when Alvin Gentry was fired. Johnson is the 12th head coach the Clippers have had during their 19 seasons in Los Angeles. ''What we really try to do when we go out there is get the guys to play hard. I told them from the beginning that I don't know how long it's going to take,'' said Johnson, who also was a head coach in the CBA. ''The main thing is that we have to go out and at least start to build on something and let it be continuous. Tonight we went out there and played hard.'' Gentry had an 89-133 record in almost three seasons with the Clippers but was criticized for not being tough enough on his players. Richardson had 22 points for Los Angeles and Miller had 21 -- but missed the 3-pointer at the buzzer after the Clippers attempted to rally from 10 down in the final 37 seconds. ''Basically, Coach said 'Let the team play,''' Corey Maggette said. ''We all played with a strong effort. We just have to play hard and continue to do what we have to do.'' David Wesley, held to just nine points on 3-for-10 shooting through the first three quarters, finished with 23 to help the Hornets beat the Clippers for the 14th time in their past 18 meetings. P.J. Brown added 12 points and 10 rebounds. Maggette scored 24 points and was 13-for-13 from the free-throw line for the injury-riddled Clippers, who are last in the Pacific Division at 19-40 after dropping six in a row and 15 of 18. In addition to center Michael Olowokandi, who is recovering from knee surgery, Clippers leading scorer Elton Brand missed his fourth game with a stress fracture in his lower left leg and Lamar Odom sat out because of a sprained right ankle he injured in the defeat Saturday against Seattle, leaving their new head coach at a disadvantage. But the Clippers, inspired by an animated Johnson on the sideline, hung tough throughout the game. ''They did what I asked them to do on the sideline,'' Johnson said. ''When I asked them to double-team, they did that.'' However, New Orleans' Kenny Anderson scored nine of his 11 points in the fourth quarter, including a pair of free throws that gave the Hornets a 109-100 lead. ''I was happy for Kenny. He came in and gave us a big lift,'' Hornets coach Paul Silas said. ''It seems that everybody I put in right now is focused and ready to play. These guys have just played unbelievable, and I can't say enough about them.'' Richardson made a pair of 3-pointers and Miller hit a layup to narrow the gap to 110-108 with seven seconds left. Anderson then made one of two foul shots for the Hornets. Clippers rookie Chris Wilcox grabbed the rebound and flung it ahead to Miller, whose last-second 25-footer bounced off the rim. ''We did what we had to do to win the game,'' Mashburn said. ''In order to make this a successful road trip, we had to get this game.'' Game notes
Johnson and Silas were teammates on Seattle's 1978-79 NBA championship team, with Johnson being named MVP of the Finals that year. Both players have had their respective uniform numbers retired by the Boston Celtics -- although Silas' No. 35 wasn't retired until after the heart-related death of Reggie Lewis in 1993. ... Johnson is the fourth player from the Celtics' 1986 championship team to become an NBA head coach, joining Larry Bird (Indiana), Danny Ainge (Phoenix) and Rick Carlisle (Boston). ... Of the Clippers' past 14 head coaches dating back to Silas in 1980-81, the only ones to win their first game were Silas, Mike Schueler, Larry Brown and Bob Weiss. ... Silas was already the Clippers' coach when Donald Sterling assumed ownership of the club and moved it from San Diego to Los Angeles before the 1984-85 season. Since then, the franchise is 571-1,178 (.326).
